title: 4  Summary

In summary, this book has no content whatsoever.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
This is a book created from markdown and executable code.
See Knuth (1984) for additional discussion of literate programming.
And also check out McElreath (2018) for the coolest book around!




Knuth, Donald E. 1984. “Literate Programming.” Comput. J. 27 (2): 97–111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.


McElreath, Richard. 2018. Statistical Rethinking: A Bayesian Course with Examples in r and Stan. Chapman; Hall/CRC.

title: 3  Statistical Rethinking Notes
2  Papers
text:
This is where you put notes of papers that you have read.
Why probability probably doesn’t exist (but it is useful to act like it does) Spiegelhalter (2024)

Despite the widespread application of probability in scientific disciplines, there is no consensus on its precise definition or ontological status.
He suggests that probability may not exist as a tangible entity but serves as a valuable conceptual tool for modeling uncertainty and making informed decisions.
This perspective challenges traditional interpretations and encourages a more nuanced understanding of probability’s role in scientific inquiry.
By adopting probabilistic reasoning, scientists and statisticians can effectively navigate uncertainty and draw meaningful conclusions, underscoring the importance of probability as a methodological construct.





Spiegelhalter, David. 2024. “Why Probability Probably Doesn’t Exist (but It Is Useful to Act Like It Does).” Nature 636 (8043): 560–63.
